title: 108_s480
content: The Act may be cited as the "Training for Realtime Writers Act of 2004". Congress finds that the Federal Communications Commission has mandated closed captioning for television programming, with new programs required to be fully captioned starting in 2006. Approximately 28 million Americans, including 24,000 children born each year with hearing loss, rely on captioning services for participation in mainstream activities. According to a study by the National Council on Aging, a significant percentage of Americans over the age of 65, 70, and 75 are hearing impaired. The study also suggests a link between hearing loss and depression in older adults. Additionally, research shows that captions can improve reading performance for various groups, including remedial readers, young children, and illiterate adults. Over the past 5 years, student enrollment in programs training court reporters as realtime writers has significantly decreased, leading to program closures on many campuses. This decline affects 27,000,000 illiterate adults and 30,000,000 individuals for whom English is a second language. Authorization of grant program to promote training and job placement of realtime writers. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration will provide grants to eligible court reporting programs to train individuals as realtime writers for closed captioning of video programming. Eligible entities must meet educational and financial standards and be accredited by a recognized agency. The Department of Education will provide grants to eligible entities participating in student aid programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary of Commerce will prioritize entities with the capability to increase training for realtime writers, collaborate with educational institutions and businesses, or propose innovative approaches for training and job placement. The Department of Education will provide grants to eligible entities for realtime writer training. Grants will be for a two-year period with a maximum amount of $1,500,000. SEC. 4. APPLICATION. To apply for a grant under section 3, an eligible entity must submit an application to the National Telecommunications and Information Administration with specific information, including details on the training and assistance to be funded and performance measures for evaluating progress. The eligible entity must describe how scholarships will lead to employment as realtime writers, ensure continuation of training after the grant period, and collaborate with local workforce boards to support workforce goals for disadvantaged individuals and displaced workers. The eligible entity must provide additional information for priority in grant-making and any other required information as per Administration guidelines. SEC. 5. USE OF FUNDS. An eligible entity receiving a grant under section 3 must use the funds for recruitment, training, job placement, scholarships, curriculum development, distance learning, and job assistance for individuals, including those with disabilities, pursuing a career in realtime writing. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration provides scholarships based on financial need for recipients to enter into agreements to provide realtime writing services for a specified period. The Administration also sets requirements for coursework and employment related to the scholarships. The National Telecommunications and Information Administration provides scholarships for realtime writers based on financial need. Recipients must meet requirements for coursework, employment, and repayment of scholarship amounts. Administrative costs are limited to 5% of the grant amount. Grants under this Act are meant to supplement, not supplant, other funds for training and placement of realtime writers. SEC. 6. REPORTS. Each eligible entity receiving a grant under section 3 must submit an annual report to the National Telecommunications and Information Administration detailing the use of grant funds and assessing the effectiveness of activities in increasing the number of realtime writers. The final report should also include a description of the best practices. The annual report for entities receiving grants must detail best practices for increasing the number of trained, employed, and retained realtime writers. The Act authorizes appropriations for competitive grants to train court reporters and closed captioners for realtime writing under the Telecommunications Act of 1996. $20,000,000 is allocated for each fiscal year from 2004 to 2006, with additional funds as needed for 2007.
